captions.text:
Now, I&#39;m no video game marketing expert; my main 
advice for video game marketers is &quot;place the

barrel in your mouth and aim upwards to hit the 
pituitary gland.&quot; Whoops, that&#39;ll demonetize us,

but I&#39;m pretty sure page one of Video Game 
Marketing for Dummies is to make sure your game is

visible and memorable. As such, making your game 
an Epic Store exclusive is already putting it on

the back foot as that fulfils the first criterion 
about as well as pushing it off a cruise ship in

the middle of the night, but you&#39;re really not 
gonna turn things around by calling it—actually,

quick test. Without looking at the video 
title, what am I reviewing this week? If

you hadn&#39;t heard of it before, I&#39;d honestly be 
surprised if your memory held onto it between

clicking the thumbnail and now. Blades of Fire. 
Even now, I had to double check it wasn&#39;t Blades

of Fury or Crotch of Burning or something like 
that. Anyway, Blades of Fire might sound like

a Netflix documentary about roller derbies but is 
actually a new game from the devs of Castlevania:

Lords of Shadow. Another world-beater in the 
Forgettable Titles Showcase. The &quot;Castlevania&quot;

bit does all the work; &quot;Lords of Shadow&quot; sits on 
it like a newspaper hat on an important dignitary.

Our protagonist is Aran de Lira, a gruff, hairy 
dad with one of those names that really looks

like it should be an anagram of something. Give me 
a second. Holy shit. ANAL RAIDER? I was kidding.

Aran is minding his own business in his 
secluded house in the forest when goons

from the local evil empire show up and he has 
to rescue from them a scholarly teenage boy

and the magical MacGuffin he&#39;s carrying, at 
which point, Aran goes, &quot;Blimey, this call to

adventure could only get more generic if you&#39;d 
murdered my parents on the way here. Suppose

I&#39;d better journey across the land and murder 
the evil queen, then. I&#39;m a busy protagonist,

and I haven&#39;t got time for a refusal of the call 
right now.&quot; And thus, Aran&#39;s adventure begins,

accompanied by scholar boy in an almost straight 
example of the standard hairy dad dynamic,

except instead of becoming surrogate dad to a 
headstrong young girl, Aran instead spends the

game grooming a beautiful, hairless twink. And 
we&#39;re certainly demonetized now if we weren&#39;t

already. Considering Aran has both the build 
and hairdo of a heavy metal roadie who always

gets lumped with the job of transporting 
the guitars made of depleted uranium.

He&#39;s hauntingly similar to the protagonist of 
Lords of Shadow, and the whole mythic fantasy

setting has much the same vibes as well, 
but while Lords of Shadow was dismissed by

us tosspots as supermarket own-brand God 
of War, Blades of Forgotten it Again has

come a long way and graduated to being 
supermarket own-brand Elden Ring. So,

we have your usual Soulslike format: explore 
the semi-open world, find bonfire checkpoints,

run into a lot of very burly dudes who all want 
to play matchmaker between your throat and your

lower intestine. But Blades of for Fuck&#39;s Sake, 
What Was it Called Again? can&#39;t match Elden Ring

for grandness of environment design. Its areas 
feel cramped and confusing to navigate; it&#39;s

easy to get turned around and confused by paths 
that look the same. What doesn&#39;t help is that I

kept picking up keys without noticing; they were 
dropped by enemies and automatically picked up,

and I&#39;d miss the little info window letting me 
know &#39;cause I was too busy teabagging the corpse,

and then after circling a mazelike castle four 
times, I&#39;d finally in desperation try one of

the locked doors again, and bing! Turns out you 
picked the key up at some point, thicko. What,

did you lose it up your catamite&#39;s rectum? Should 
have been more diligent with your Anal Raiding.

So, no ticks for level design. The main gimmick 
of the game is that Aran has to forge all his own

weapons in a system where the durability of the 
weapon is decided by a little minigame that&#39;s like

a cross between minigolf and pushing the bubbles 
out of wallpaper and about half as exciting as

that sounds, and you can micromanage the shape and 
materials for every single part of the weapon to

an impressive degree, although pretty much every 
choice comes down to &quot;make do more damage&quot; or

&quot;make quicker and use less stamina.&quot; And then 
we can&#39;t move on until we come up with a name

for each weapon we make. Look, game, I can see 
you&#39;re trying to get me invested, but calling

it Bum Biter isn&#39;t going to save this thing from 
getting chucked in the recycle bin the moment I

can craft something with greener numbers. Whenever 
you die, instead of a bloodstain, you drop your

currently equipped weapon and have to run back to 
get it, which can be very annoying if it was your

best weapon, or indeed your only weapon capable 
of damaging the surrounding enemies who are

frequently immune to at least one damage type, 
but this is probably also supposed to make us

invested. &quot;What will you do now, poor Bum Biter? 
Abandoned alone among monsters like a child losing

their dad in the middle of a Brony convention, 
wondering even now if it will ever feel your

reassuring presence around its hilt again.&quot; Yeah, 
probably just make a new one, actually. Call me

a monster, but we all know that kid wasn&#39;t 
coming out of that Brony convention the same.

The other gimmick is the combat itself. Instead of 
the traditional light attack/heavy attack, we can

attack in one of four directions with the face 
buttons. Which... works. It only really matters

if enemies are only weak from one direction, like 
they forgot to wear their armored bollock guards

this morning, or if the terrain is blocking 
attacks from certain angles, but that&#39;s not

nothing. Lord knows, whenever a finishing blow in 
Dark Souls was blocked by an inconvenient doorway,

I&#39;d scream aloud for my dude to get into their 
hollow skull that there are a whole 359 different

angles we could be approaching this from. My 
other tick is for the character design; much

as with Lords of Shadow, these devs seem to have 
a great imagination for memorable characters with

unique looks that wouldn&#39;t go amiss in something 
like The NeverEnding Story or Labyrinth or one

of those other classic &#39;90s child traumatizers. 
But do these ticks add up to the Lyme disease of

recommendation? Not really. The writing doesn&#39;t 
sell the story for me. There&#39;s no chemistry or

conflict between the game&#39;s two leads, aside 
from the boy occasionally tokenly reminding

Aran that he&#39;s old and Aran in turn reminding him 
that he&#39;s a twat with admittedly tight buttocks.

See, after giving Aran the MacGuffin in the 
intro, the kid&#39;s role in the game seems to be

mainly just drawing pictures of the monsters we 
fight, occasionally triumphantly announcing he&#39;s

finished the current drawing, at which point Aran 
goes, &quot;Great job! I&#39;m glad you&#39;re around!&quot; and I

honestly couldn&#39;t tell if he was being sarcastic. 
For all its creativity, the game doesn&#39;t put

the work in to make me invested in events. The 
prologue sets up that Aran&#39;s heading off to kill

the evil queen, right? But then two minutes later, 
he decides on a whim to kill some other bloke who

happens to be on the way, and we&#39;re stuck doing 
that for the next 20 hours or so. Hope the evil

queen&#39;s got some magazines handy. The game is full 
of mystifyingly bad story choices, like for one

prolonged section, forcing us to wait 30 seconds 
over and over again while a forgetful ghost

stands around trying to remember how to proceed 
before going, &quot;Oh! Turns out, the very obviously

button-shaped thing on the wall is the button 
to open the door. Cue contextual button prompt.&quot;

Blades of Fffffffffrrrrt is, in summary, a couple 
of neat ideas perched atop an old, unreliable, and

singularly unremarkable donkey that keeps stopping 
every now and again to do a very boring poo.
